channel.title: NYT > World News

item.title: After the Assad Regime’s Fall, His Enforcers Are Lying Low and Living Large
item.description: A Times investigation into the whereabouts of top Syrian officials who fled after the regime’s fall shows many remain free — shielded by wealth and accommodating host nations.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Neil Collier, Danny Makki and Ahmad Mhidi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: As Trump Clings to Tariffs, His Argentine Ally Is Opening Up to Trade
item.description: President Javier Milei is eliminating barriers to what had been a closed-off economy, moving in the opposite direction of his main political ally, President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Lucía Cholakian Herrera and Sarah Pabst
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers standing in line for the opening of Decathlon, a sporting goods store, last month in Buenos Aires.

item.title: What We Know About U.S. Interceptions of Oil Tankers in Venezuela
item.description: A Venezuela-bound vessel fled after rebuffing an attempt by the Coast Guard to seize it, the latest twist in the escalating U.S. pressure campaign against the Maduro government.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via U.S. Homeland Security Secretary
item.media:description: A frame grab from a video posted on social media by Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, showed a helicopter flying over Centuries, another oil tanker, which was intercepted by the U.S. Coast Guard on Saturday.

item.title: Christmas Is Back in Bethlehem, but Peace and Joy Have Yet to Arrive
item.description: Palestinian Christians are reviving their seasonal public celebrations, hoping to bring light and holiday spirit at the end of a gloomy year in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Fatima AbdulKarim
item.media:credit: Hazem Bader/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Lynching of a Hindu in Bangladesh Fans Fears of Rising Intolerance
item.description: Muslim co-workers accused the garment factory worker of blasphemy and dragged him into the street, where an angry mob murdered him.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Abdul Goni/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Students held a silent protest at Dhaka University in Bangladesh’s capital on Sunday to condemn the lynching of a Hindu garment worker.

item.title: Russian General Is Killed in Car Bombing in Moscow
item.description: The attack appeared to be the latest targeted assassination of a senior military official inside Russia’s borders.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Alexander Nemenov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene of a car bombing in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: Angering Denmark, Trump Appoints Special Envoy to Greenland
item.description: President Trump, who has long said he wants to “get” the semiautonomous Danish territory, tapped Louisiana’s governor for the new position. Officials in Greenland and Denmark expressed outrage.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg, Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Jeff Landry of Louisiana with President Trump at the White House in March.

item.title: U.K. Man and 5 Others Charged With Sexual Offenses Against His Wife
item.description: Philip Young, 49, is accused of drugging and raping the woman over a 13-year period. Five other men have been charged in the same case.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:credit: Ian Pilbeam/Alamy
item.media:description: Philip Young, 49, is set to appear in a magistrates court in Swindon, in southwest England, on Tuesday.

item.title: Carney Names Financier Mark Wiseman as Canada’s U.S. Ambassador
item.description: Mark Wiseman has held high-profile roles in law, business consulting and finance, and will lead Canada’s efforts to reboot diplomatic relation with Washington at a critical moment.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Mike Segar/Reuters
item.media:description: Mark Wiseman, a Canadian financial executive, has been named Canada’s ambassador to the United States at a crucial moment in relations between the countries.

item.title: Bondi Beach Gunmen Also Used Pipe Bombs in Attack, Police Say
item.description: But the explosives did not detonate, according to investigators, who also found a video of the two men training with firearms.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police at a memorial at Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia, on Sunday.

item.title: More Abducted Nigerian Children Are Released, Government Says
item.description: A spokesman for the Nigerian government said the “remaining” students taken from a Catholic school had been freed, but the local diocese said that only a “second batch” had been released.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Saikou Jammeh
item.media:credit: Chenemi Bamaiyi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Children who were released after being kidnapped last month from a school in northwestern Nigeria sit in a hall after their arrival at the state capital in Minna, Nigeria, on Monday.

item.title: Assad, Ousted Syrian Ruler, Leads Life of Luxury in Russia
item.description: Bashar al-Assad’s long, brutal reign ended swiftly, but he and his close circle have had a soft landing in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis and Ahmad Mhidi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: At Bondi Beach, Australians Mourn Shooting Victims
item.description: Thousands gathered a week after gunmen killed 15 people at a Hanukkah celebration. But hints of political divisions and anti-immigration rhetoric have emerged.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crowd in Sydney, Australia, sang “Waltzing Matilda” on Sunday in honor of a child killed in the Dec. 14 attack at a Hanukkah celebration on Bondi Beach.

item.title: U.S. Coast Guard Pursues Oil Tanker Linked to Venezuela
item.description: The latest vessel to be targeted by the United States in its pressure campaign on Venezuela was sending distress signals as it headed northeast from the Caribbean into the Atlantic.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Christiaan Triebert, Tyler Pager, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Department of Homeland Security, via Reuters
item.media:description: A U.S. military helicopter flying over the Panama-flagged Centuries, which was intercepted on Saturday east of Barbados in the Caribbean Sea. The Coast Guard was also pursuing another tanker, the Bella 1.

item.title: After Bondi Massacre, a Moment of Unity. Then, Bitter Partisanship.
item.description: The political point scoring that has erupted after the terror attack last week is unusual in Australia, where leaders tend to unite after catastrophes.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Matthew Abbott
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia and his wife leaving a memorial in Sydney on Sunday. Thousands had gathered on Bondi Beach a week after the attack there.

item.title: China Delays Plans for Mass Production of Self-Driving Cars After Accident
item.description: After years of planning for cars that would let drivers take their hands off the wheel and eyes off the road, China’s regulators have become more cautious.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.category: Guangzhou Xiaopeng Motors Technology Co Ltd (Xpeng Motors)
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Changan Automobile assembly line in May. Changan is one of only two automakers approved to conduct limited testing of self-driving taxis.

item.title: Trump Administration Orders Nearly 30 U.S. Ambassadors to Leave Their Posts
item.description: A union representing career diplomats said such a mass recall had never happened in the history of the U.S. Foreign Service.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration did not give a reason for the recalls and has not publicly announced them.

item.title: Trump Administration Oil Tanker Seizures Are Meant to Force Maduro Out, Officials Say
item.description: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said the ship seizures were meant to force Venezuela’s president Nicolás Maduro from power.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Department of Homeland Security
item.media:description: On Saturday, the Coast Guard boarded the Centuries, a Panamanian-flagged tanker that had recently loaded Venezuelan crude oil, reportedly for a Chinese trader.

item.title: Two New Banksy Murals Appear in London
item.description: Two new London murals, widely attributed to the mysterious street artist, combine seasonal themes with what appears to be social commentary on rising child homelessness in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A new mural by the artist Banksy appeared in Bayswater, in central London, on Monday.

item.title: Understanding Male Loneliness
item.description: Why is it harder for men to have intimate friendships into adulthood?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: Puzzle Designers Search for That ‘Satisfying Click’
item.description: For prizewinning puzzle creators, the devilish ideas are in the details.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Élysée Palace Silver and Tableware Stolen by Steward, Prosecutors Say
item.description: In what prosecutors say was an inside job, copper pots, porcelain and Baccarat Champagne glasses were stolen from the inventory of the Élysée Palace.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Julien Hekimian/Getty Images
item.media:description: The entrance to the Élysée Palace in Paris. The objects that disappeared from its collection were returned after the investigation, according to prosecutors.

item.title: Russia Dismisses Reports of Progress in Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: Proposals that emerged in recent negotiations with the United States were “rather unconstructive,” a Kremlin official said on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Markus Schreiber
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, met with a representative of Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, in Miami this weekend.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Will Deliver Britain’s ‘Alternative Christmas Message’
item.description: Mr. Kimmel will speak out against fascism and about the importance of free speech in the holiday address, according to a Channel 4 spokesman.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Richard Shotwell/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jimmy Kimmel will share “his personal reflections on the year,” according to Channel 4.

item.title: The Sibling Bond
item.description: Parenting is closely studied, but sibling relationships have gotten much less attention.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: ‘Orwellian Climate of Fear’: How China Cracks Down on Critics in the U.S.
item.description: The Chinese government once focused on political dissidents and exiled activists. Now, federal officials say, it is targeting artists in the United States whose creative protests test its tolerance.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker and Alicia Chen
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Freed From a Belarus Prison, a Nobel Peace Laureate Experiences ‘Oxygen Intoxication’
item.description: Ales Bialiatski, who shared the Nobel in 2022, described long hours of backbreaking work and stints in solitary confinement.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Gonzalo Fuentes/Reuters
item.media:description: Ales Bialiatski, flanked by a Belarusian opposition leader, Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, outside the U.S. embassy, in Vilnius, Lithuania, this month.

item.title: When Something Goes Wrong With Your Flight, These People Take Charge
item.description: Inside a tornado-hardened office in Texas, 1,700 American Airlines employees manage the carrier’s operations, responding to bad weather, plane trouble and ailing passengers.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Desiree Rios
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Sydney Shooting Suspects Met Muslim Leaders in Philippines, Officials Say
item.description: Intelligence authorities in the Philippines say the father and son apparently slipped out of Davao City during their monthlong stay, but details remain sketchy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan/Getty Images
item.media:description: A soldier inspecting a bus at a checkpoint along a highway in Davao City, Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: Guns from the United States are Pouring into Canada, Fueling a Spike in Gun Violence
item.description: The proliferation of illegal firearms from the United States has fueled a spike in gun violence in Canada, where most guns used in crimes are smuggled across the border.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seized guns at the Toronto Police Service. In Ontario, Canada’s most populous province, which includes Toronto, 91 percent of handguns recovered from crimes in 2024 came from the United States.

item.title: 9 Killed in Mass Shooting at Tavern in South Africa
item.description: Around a dozen gunmen opened fire at bar patrons, the police said. A manhunt for the unknown assailants was underway.
item.dc:creator: Zimasa Matiwane and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Emmanuel Croset/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of an attack at a tavern near Johannesburg on Sunday.

item.title: The Pompidou Center Has Been Emptied of Its Art. We Watched It Happen.
item.description: The Pompidou Center is the place to see contemporary art in Paris. Or it was, until curators put its astonishing collection into storage.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:credit: Simon Hantaï/2025 Archives Simon Hantaï/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York/ADAGP, Paris; Photo: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tabula, 1974, by Simon Hantaï.

item.title: How China Tried to Dismantle a Major Underground Church
item.description: Videos and photographs show how the Chinese authorities have tried to dismantle Zion Church, a Christian network with branches across the country.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Long Before Bondi Massacre, Australian Jews Lived With a Sense of Peril
item.description: Armed guards, bollards and secretive precautions became part of life amid antisemitic attacks and blurred lines between anger at Israel and hatred of Jews.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Matthew Abbott
item.media:description: Rebecca Di Veroli with her daughter, Chloe, preparing the family’s menorah at home in North Bondi on Sunday.

item.title: A Neighborhood in India Fears Being Blamed for a Distant Atrocity
item.description: The attacker killed at last week’s Hanukkah celebration in Australia came from a Muslim area whose residents have long gone abroad to seek better lives.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Toli Chowki, an area of the southern Indian city of Hyderabad with many Muslim residents, has been in an unwelcome spotlight in recent days.

item.title: Passenger Train in India Hits Elephant Herd, Killing Seven
item.description: No people were injured in the accident, despite a partial derailment. As elephant habitat shrinks, such deadly encounters are on the rise.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Anupam Nath/Associated Press
item.media:description: Workers making repairs after a train hit a herd of elephants early Saturday in northeastern India.

item.title: U.S. Strikes on Syria Underscore Scale of Challenge for Its President
item.description: The Syrian government did not comment directly on the extensive U.S. strikes targeting the Islamic State on Friday but said it was intensifying its own efforts to fight the group.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian government forces at a checkpoint on the outskirts of Damascus in April. The U.S. launched airstrikes against the Islamic State in central Syria on Friday.

item.title: Closing Arguments
item.description: Today, your highly personal, delightfully specific bests of 2025.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Best of 2025, Canada Edition
item.description: Here are the Canadian standouts from The Times’s culture, books and arts coverage over the last year.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Richard Drew/Associated Press
item.media:description: Margaret Atwood’s memoir is one of The Times’s Notable Books of 2025.

item.title: With Attacks on Oil Tankers, Ukraine Takes Aim at Russia’s War Financing
item.description: Strikes on four vessels signal that Kyiv is willing to expand the maritime theater of the conflict in an effort to crimp Moscow’s military funding.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Ephrat Livni and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Satellite-controlled speedboat drones designed and operated by Ukraine’s military intelligence service. Called Sea Babies, they are packed with explosives and can travel long distances.

item.title: What Fans Did to Attend a Bad Bunny Show in Mexico City
item.description: The award-winning Puerto Rican artist, the most-streamed on the planet, is performing eight concerts in Mexico. People flocked from all over the world, including the United States.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Luis Antonio Rojas
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times

item.title: A Woman Froze to Death on an Alpine Trek. Is Her Boyfriend to Blame?
item.description: A man in Austria was charged in the death of his girlfriend after leaving her behind, in a case testing ideas of freedom and responsibility in the mountains.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Kerstin Joensson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Grossglockner, Austria’s highest mountain, seen from the nearby Sonnblick Observatory.

item.title: U.S. and Venezuela Jam Caribbean GPS Signals to Thwart Attacks, Raising Flight Hazard
item.description: Military brinkmanship between President Trump and Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela has led to an increase in electronic warfare in the region.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of Venezuela’s security forces on the tarmac at Maiquetia International Airport in Caracas this month. The F.A.A. has issued a warning to all aircraft operating there.

item.title: Hezbollah Is Down, but Not Out, as Lebanon Faces Pressure to Disarm It
item.description: The Lebanese militant group has resisted calls to lay down all its arms, risking a return to war with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Euan Ward, Natan Odenheimer and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters gathered around the grave of Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s former leader, who was killed by an Israeli airstrike, on the anniversary of his death, in Dahiya, Lebanon, in September.

item.title: Taiwan’s Subway Stabber Planned His Deadly Spree, Police Say
item.description: Investigators said they were unsure of the attacker’s motives. But clues pointed to an isolated and increasingly troubled life, and no accomplices.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taipei Main Station on Friday evening, where the attacker threw smoke bombs and began his stabbing spree.

item.title: Sudanese Refugees Describe Their Escape From Darfur
item.description: No one knows the true toll of the massacre, and the city remains isolated. Now, refugee camps in Chad are flooded with newly displaced Sudanese.
item.dc:creator: Ivor Prickett
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Where’s the Humanity?’ Bondi Attack Leaves Suspects’ Neighborhood Stunned.
item.description: The alleged gunmen in the shooting, Sajid Akram, 50, and his son, Naveed Akram, 24, were from Bonnyrigg, a diverse, multilingual suburb miles from Sydney’s Bondi Beach.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka, Max Kim and Matthew Abbott
item.media:description: A pedestrian path over a main road on Friday in Bonnyrigg, a multicultural suburb of Sydney.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Islamic State Targets in Syria
item.description: American forces struck dozens of suspected ISIS sites, making good on President Trump’s vow to avenge two American soldiers and a civilian U.S. interpreter killed by the group last week.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The dignified transfer of the American soldiers killed in Syria. The assault last weekend was a stark reminder of the danger in the region and the quandary of whether to keep American forces there at all.

item.title: Toss a Coin in the Trevi Fountain? That’ll Be 2 Euros, Wish Not Included
item.description: Starting on Feb. 1, Rome will charge tourists a fee to go down into the basin of the famed 18th-century fountain. Not every one is happy (except Romans, who won’t have to pay).
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Andrew Medichini/Associated Press
item.media:description: Visitors admiring the Trevi Fountain in Rome, on Friday. The small square around it is often densely packed.

item.title: How Venezuela Went From U.S. Ally to Trump Target
item.description: Closely tied to Washington during much of the Cold War, Venezuela has gone through political upheavals over the years that now make it a major enemy in the eyes of the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Henry Griffin/Associated Press
item.media:description: Venezuelans surrounding Vice President Richard M. Nixon’s motorcade in Caracas in 1958.

item.title: Toronto Man Accused of Working With ISIS Faces Terror Charges Targeting Jews and Women
item.description: After two failed abductions, three men were arrested, one of whom is charged with working to support the Islamic State terrorist group.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Eugen Sakhnenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The skyline of Toronto. Terror charges were filed after investigations into two failed kidnapping attempts in the Toronto area earlier this year.

item.title: Three Killed in Stabbing Attack in Taiwan
item.description: The attacker, who threw smoke grenades inside a train station in Taiwan’s capital, later continued his rampage nearby and died in falling from a building.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: An injured woman being transported in the Zhongshan area of Taipei, Taiwan, after a knife attack on Friday.

item.title: What We Know About the Suspects in the Bondi Beach Shooting
item.description: The police named Sajid Akram, 50, and his son, Naveed Akram, 24, as the suspects in the shooting that claimed 15 lives on Dec. 14.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police conducting a search operation at a house in a suburb of Sydney, Australia, on Sunday.

item.title: To Secure Money for Ukraine, Europe Had to Resort to a Messy Compromise
item.description: The European Union came up with an 11th-hour deal to help Ukraine, but the solution raised questions about the bloc’s decisiveness.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a mortar, hidden from the sight of drones, near Kupiansk, in May. The European Union will funnel 90 billion euros’ worth of loans to Ukraine.

item.title: After Bondi Beach Shooting, Australia Debates New Laws to Restrict Speech and Protests
item.description: The authorities are vowing to crack down after a mass shooting at a Jewish holiday celebration. Experts say that what the country needs might not be new laws.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers at Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, two days after gunmen killed 15 people at a Jewish celebration.

item.title: Gaza City Famine Averted, Global Experts Say, but Palestinians Face Major Difficulties Accessing Food
item.description: Food security experts said a famine reported in August had been alleviated but that the situation remained dire across the enclave, despite a cease-fire in October and greater flows of aid.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians lining up to receive food packages during a distribution in a town in the central Gaza Strip.

item.title: Riots Erupt in Bangladesh After the Killing of a Student Leader
item.description: Newspaper buildings were set on fire after the death of an activist who was attacked recently. Political leaders fear more violence could derail attempts to restore democracy.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Abdul Goni/Reuters
item.media:description: Crowds in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Friday near the office of the Prothom Alo newspaper, where a targeted arson occurred after the death of Sharif Osman bin Hadi, a student leader.

item.title: Trump Signs Law Repealing Tough Sanctions on Syria
item.description: The Caesar Act was imposed in 2019 in response to widespread and systematic violations of human rights by the regime of former dictator Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Reham Mourshed
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A heavily damaged neighborhood in the eastern city of Deir al-Zour, Syria, in August. The lifting of U.S. sanctions will bolster Syria’s new government’s efforts to rebuild a nation in ruins.

item.title: With New E.U. Loan, Ukraine Avoids Budget Crunch and Can Plan War Effort
item.description: The loan will cover two-thirds of the country’s financial needs for the next two years. It also bolsters Ukraine’s position in ongoing peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Ukraine’s 148th Artillery Brigade at a firing position in the Zaporizhzhia region of eastern Ukraine, in October.
